articles.headline: Justices Reject Ban on Videos of Animal Cruelty
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court, in a major First Amendment ruling, voted 8-1  to strike down a federal law that made it a crime to create or sell dogfight videos.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court, in a major First Amendment ruling, voted 8-1  to strike down a federal law that made it a crime to create or sell dogfight videos.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a major First Amendment ruling, the Supreme Court on Tuesday struck down a federal law that made it a crime to create or sell dogfight videos and other depictions of animal cruelty.

articles.headline: Airbus’s Parent Gambles on Tanker Contract
articles.snippet: The decision by EADS to bid for a contract worth at least $35 billion came six weeks after its partner, Northrop Grumman, dropped out of the contest.
articles.abstract: The decision by EADS to bid for a contract worth at least $35 billion came six weeks after its partner, Northrop Grumman, dropped out of the contest.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Pentagon’s long-running effort to buy aerial refueling tankers for the Air Force took another twist on Tuesday when a European company decided that instead of walking away, it would compete with Boeing for a contract worth at least $35 billion.

articles.headline: War of Words Regarding the Financial Overhaul
articles.snippet: Senate Democrats stepped up efforts to paint Republicans the color of Wall Street as the two sides debate regulation.
articles.abstract: Senate Democrats stepped up efforts to paint Republicans the color of Wall Street as the two sides debate regulation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hoping to seize on populist fury on a day when Goldman Sachs reported blockbuster earnings, Senate Democrats on Tuesday sought to portray Republicans as siding with wealthy Wall Street interests in opposing tougher financial regulations.
articles.byline: By David M. Herszenhorn and Edward Wyatt

articles.headline: At Top University, a Fight for Pakistan’s Future
articles.snippet: An attack on a professor revealed a power struggle between an educated class and those pushing an intolerant vision of Islam.
articles.abstract: An attack on a professor revealed a power struggle between an educated class and those pushing an intolerant vision of Islam.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAHORE, Pakistan — The professor was working in his office here on the campus of Pakistan’s largest university this month when members of an Islamic student group battered open the door, beat him with metal rods and bashed him over the head with a giant flower pot.

articles.headline: Questions for Banks That Put Together Deals
articles.snippet: Deals in the Securities and Exchange Commission’s case against Goldman extended far past that investment bank.
articles.abstract: Deals in the Securities and Exchange Commission’s case against Goldman extended far past that investment bank.
articles.lead_paragraph: They were the black boxes of the subprime era, byzantine creations of the brightest minds on Wall Street that made — and then lost — vast fortunes.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Eric Dash

articles.headline: A State With Plenty of Jobs but Few Places to Live
articles.snippet: Amid an oil boom, North Dakota has a novel problem: plenty of jobs, but nowhere to put the workers.
articles.abstract: Amid an oil boom, North Dakota has a novel problem: plenty of jobs, but nowhere to put the workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WILLISTON, N.D. — When Joey Scott arrived here recently from Montana, he had no trouble finding work — he signed almost immediately with a company working to drill in the oil fields. But finding housing was another matter.

articles.headline: Mumbai Hotel, a Killing Zone, Is Grand Again
articles.snippet: Devastated by a terrorist attack in November 2008 that killed 163 people, the Oberoi has reopened as a proud luxury hotel.
articles.abstract: Devastated by a terrorist attack in November 2008 that killed 163 people, the Oberoi has reopened as a proud luxury hotel.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — On Wednesday, the Oberoi Hotel, one of two five-star hotel complexes attacked by 10 Pakistan-based gunmen in November 2008, will welcome its first guests after a comprehensive $45 million reconstruction.

articles.headline: When Heart Devices Fail, Who Should Be Blamed?
articles.snippet: Doctors in a landmark medical device case ask who should be held responsible when a company sells flawed products.
articles.abstract: Doctors in a landmark medical device case ask who should be held responsible when a company sells flawed products.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was a landmark episode brought to light by two Minneapolis cardiologists that changed the way the medical device industry deals with the safety of heart implants.

articles.headline: Financial Debate Renews Scrutiny on Banks’ Size
articles.snippet: In financial legislation before the Senate, there is no attempt to break up big banks as a means of creating a less risky financial system.
articles.abstract: In financial legislation before the Senate, there is no attempt to break up big banks as a means of creating a less risky financial system.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One question has vexed the Obama administration and Congress since the start of the financial crisis: how to prevent big bank bailouts.

articles.headline: Bank Says Losses Prove No Ill Intent
articles.snippet: People with knowledge of Goldman’s trading paint a nuanced picture of the bank’s practices during the period of the so-called Abacus 2007-AC1 deal.
articles.abstract: People with knowledge of Goldman’s trading paint a nuanced picture of the bank’s practices during the period of the so-called Abacus 2007-AC1 deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fabrice P. Tourre was in a bind: his seemingly lucrative deal for Goldman Sachs was going horribly wrong.

articles.headline: In Sour Home Market, Buying Often Beats Renting
articles.snippet: For much of the last decade, renting has been a better financial move than buying, but the tide is turning.
articles.abstract: For much of the last decade, renting has been a better financial move than buying, but the tide is turning.
articles.lead_paragraph: In much of the country, for much of the last decade, renting a home has usually been a better financial move than buying one. It’s been true in Southern California, San Francisco, Phoenix, Las Vegas and large parts of Florida, the Pacific Northwest and the Northeast.
